tit.e: Montsuki Haori Hakama (Japanese formal attire for men)
Montsuki Haori Hakama (Japanese formal attire for men)
Montsuki Haori Hakama (Japanese formal attire for men)

sen.j: 紋付羽織袴（もんつきはおりはかま）は、現在一般的に和服における男子の第一礼服とされる衣服。
sen.e: "Montsuki Haori Hakama" is a Japanese traditional costume that is commonly regarded as the most formal attire for men at present.
"Montsuki Haori Hakama" is a Japanese traditional costume that is commonly regarded as the most formal attire for men at present.
"Montsuki Haori Hakama" is a Japanese traditional costume that is commonly regarded as the most formal attire for men at present.

sen.j: 紋付の長着に袴をはき、紋付の羽織を着ける。
sen.e: It is a combination of crested nagagi (a full-length Japanese garment), hakama (a pleated and divided Japanese skirt for men) and haori (a Japanese traditional half coat).
It is a combination of crested nagagi (a full-length Japanese garment), hakama (a pleated and divided Japanese skirt for men) and crested haori (a Japanese traditional half coat).
It is a combination of crested nagagi (a full-length Japanese garment), hakama (a pleated and divided Japanese skirt for men) and crested haori (a Japanese traditional half coat).

sen.j: 江戸時代に武家社会で略礼装として用いられていたものが、中期には庶民男子の最礼装として着用されるようになり、明治時代に太政官令で礼装を定めた際に「五つ紋の黒紋付羽織袴」を採用したことにより正装として広まった。
sen.e: In the Edo Period, people of samurai society wore it as simplified formal attire, which became the most formal wear for men of common people in the middle of the Edo Period, and which became further popular as a formal garment in the Meiji Period when the government designated "black haori hakama bearing five family crests" as official formal attire by the decree of the Grand Council of State

In the Edo period, people of samurai society wore it as simplified formal attire, which became the most formal wear for men of common people in the middle of the Edo period, and which became further popular as a formal garment in the Meiji period when the government designated 'black haori hakama bearing five family crests' as official formal attire by the decree of the Grand Council of State.
sen.cmt: Periodの頭文字を小文字に変更、ピリオド追加、シングルクォーテーションに変更
sen.e: In the Edo period, people of samurai society wore it as simplified formal attire, which became the most formal wear for men of common people in the middle of the Edo period, and which became further popular as a formal garment in the Meiji period when the government designated 'black haori hakama bearing five family crests' as official formal attire by the decree of the Grand Council of State.

sen.j: 勲章着用規定に第一種礼装として定められているために現在一般には和服の正装とされる。
sen.e: Since the decree's provision to wear a decoration stipulated this attire as the first class formal costume, it is now generally considered as formal Japanese clothes.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Since the decree's provision to wear a decoration stipulated this attire as the first class formal costume, it is now generally regarded as formal Japanese clothes.
Since the decree's provision to wear a decoration stipulated this attire as the first class formal costume, it is now generally regarded as formal Japanese clothes.

sen.j: しかし、本来は略礼装に過ぎなかった衣服であるため、伝統的な宗教・芸能などの分野では、かならずしも紋付羽織袴を正装としているわけではない。
sen.e: But, since it had originally been no more than simplified formal wear, people of traditional religions and arts of performance do not necessarily consider montsuki haori hakama as formal.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: But, since it had originally been no more than simplified formal wear, people of traditional religions and arts of performance do not necessarily consider Montsuki Haori Hakama formal.
sen.cmt: Montsuki Haori Hakamaとし、as formal→formalとしました。
sen.e: But, since it had originally been no more than simplified formal wear, people of traditional religions and arts of performance do not necessarily consider Montsuki Haori Hakama formal.

sen.j: また勲章等着用規程に措いては一等以上の勲章の正章の着用を認められていないため、洋装の最礼装である燕尾服と同等未満の扱いであり、洋装の第二礼装であるフロックコート・モーニングコートと同等の扱いとされている。
sen.e: Also, since the provision did not allow this costume to bear medals of the first order of merit or higher one, montsuki haori hakama is regarded as lower than a swallow-tailed coat, the most formal western clothes and equivalent to a frock coat or morning coat, the second class formal western clothes.

Also, since the provision did not allow this costume to bear medals of the first order of merit or higher one, Montsuki Haori Hakama is regarded as lower than a swallow-tailed coat, the most formal western clothes and equivalent to a frock coat or morning coat, the second class formal western clothes.

Also, since the provision did not allow this costume to bear medals of the first order of merit or higher one, Montsuki Haori Hakama is regarded as lower than a swallow-tailed coat, the most formal western clothes and equivalent to a frock coat or morning coat, the second class formal western clothes.

sen.j: 江戸時代の武家社会における礼装は、その者の官位により直垂・狩衣・大紋（大名の場合・忠臣蔵などで見られる）、素襖（旗本以下の場合・能、狂言の舞台で見られる）であった。
sen.e: Meanwhile, formal clothes of the people of samurai society in the Edo Period depended on their official ranks, ranging from hitatare, kariginu, daimon (worn by a feudal lord as seen in the drama "Chushingura") and suo (worn by lower ranks than Hatamoto or direct retainers of the shogun, as seen on the stages of Noh, Kyogen and other plays.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Meanwhile, formal clothes of the people of samurai society in the Edo period depended on their official ranks, ranging from hitatare, kariginu, daimon (worn by a feudal lord as seen in the drama "Chushingura") and suo (worn by lower ranks than Hatamoto or direct retainers of the shogun, as seen on the stages of Noh, Kyogen and other plays.)
sen.cmt: Periodの頭文字を小文字に変更
sen.e: Meanwhile, formal clothes of the people of samurai society in the Edo period depended on their official ranks, ranging from hitatare, kariginu, daimon (worn by a feudal lord as seen in the drama "Chushingura") and suo (worn by lower ranks than Hatamoto or direct retainers of the shogun, as seen on the stages of Noh, Kyogen and other plays.)

sen.j: いずれにしても武家以外の庶民には縁遠い服装であった。
sen.e: In any case, these formal clothes had little to do with the people other than samurai.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In any case, these formal clothes had little to do with the people other than samurai.
In any case, these formal clothes had little to do with the people other than samurai.

sen.j: 江戸時代初期には羽織の下の長着は好みでよいとされていたが、現在では黒紋付を用いることが一般的である。
sen.e: In the beginning of the Edo Period, any kind of nagagi (full-length kimono garment) could be worn under haori, but now kuro-montsuki (black crested garment) is commonly worn.
In the beginning of the Edo period, any kind of nagagi (full-length kimono garment) could be worn under haori, but now kuro-montsuki (black crested garment) is commonly worn.
sen.cmt: Periodの頭文字を小文字に変更
sen.e: In the beginning of the Edo period, any kind of nagagi (full-length kimono garment) could be worn under haori, but now kuro-montsuki (black crested garment) is commonly worn.

sen.j: 紋付と羽織に、左右の乳と袖、背（背紋）に一つずつ紋を付け、格式を重んじる行事（式典、襲名式、葬儀、結納）の際に使用される。
sen.e: People wear kimono garment and haori coat, both bearing crest marks on right and left spots of a breast part and sleeves and on a back as well, are worn on the occasion of such prestigious events as a celebration, a name-taking ceremony, a funeral and an exchange of betrothal gifts.

People wear kimono garment and haori coat, both bearing crest marks on right and left spots of a breast part and sleeves and on a back as well, are worn on the occasion of such prestigious events as a celebration, a name-taking ceremony, a funeral and an exchange of betrothal gifts.

People wear kimono garment and haori coat, both bearing crest marks on right and left spots of a breast part and sleeves and on a back as well, are worn on the occasion of such prestigious events as a celebration, a name-taking ceremony, a funeral and an exchange of betrothal gifts.

tit.e: Contents:
Contents
Contents

sen.j: 羽織：黒羽二重、五つ紋
sen.e: Haori is made up of black habutae silk cloth and five family crest marks on it.
Haori is made up of black habutae silk cloth and five family crest marks on it.
Haori is made up of black habutae silk cloth and five family crest marks on it.

sen.j: 紋は染め抜きが正式で、縫紋は略式。
sen.e: Official crest marks are dyed by leaving the pattarns undyed on its black field, while sewn crest marks are informal.
Official crest marks are dyed by leaving the pattarns undyed on its black field, while sewn crest marks are informal.
Official crest marks are dyed by leaving the pattarns undyed on its black field, while sewn crest marks are informal.

sen.j: 羽織紐は最礼装では白の平打ちだが、丸組みやそのほかの色でも差し支えない。
sen.e: White flat braids are used for haori for the most formal case, but round braids and other type braids as well as other color of the braids are acceptable.
White flat braids are used for haori for the most formal case, but round braids and other type braids as well as other color of the braids are acceptable.
White flat braids are used for haori for the most formal case, but round braids and other type braids as well as other color of the braids are acceptable.

sen.j: 葬儀の際に灰色系統のものを用いるのは明治以降の俗習。
sen.e: It is just a convention practiced after the Meiji Period to use braids of color in the grey range on the occation of funerals.
It is just a convention practiced after the Meiji period to use braids of color in the grey range on the occation of funerals.
sen.cmt: Periodの頭文字を小文字に変更
sen.e: It is just a convention practiced after the Meiji period to use braids of color in the grey range on the occation of funerals.

sen.j: 花結び等は略式で、房を上にして鳩尾の前で結ぶ。
sen.e: Braids are tied in front of the pit of the stomach, putting clusters over, while flower tie and other tying methods are informal.
Braids are tied in front of the pit of the stomach, putting clusters over, while flower tie and other tying methods are informal.
Braids are tied in front of the pit of the stomach, putting clusters over, while flower tie and other tying methods are informal.

sen.j: 長着（紋付）：黒羽二重、五つ紋
sen.e: Nagagi (montsuki, a crested full-length garment) is made up of black habutae silk cloth and five crest marks on it.
Nagagi (montsuki, a crested full-length garment) is made up of black habutae silk cloth and five crest marks on it.
Nagagi (montsuki, a crested full-length garment) is made up of black habutae silk cloth and five crest marks on it.

sen.j: 紋は染め抜きが正式で、縫紋は略式。
sen.e: Official crest marks are dyed by leaving the patterns undyed on its black field, while sewn crest marks are informal.
Official crest marks are dyed by leaving the patterns undyed on its black field, while sewn crest marks are informal.
Official crest marks are dyed by leaving the patterns undyed on its black field, while sewn crest marks are informal.

sen.j: 羽織とともに、夏場は絽や紗でもかまわない。
sen.e: During the summer season, people may wear nagagi and haori, both made of ro (gauze) or sha (silk gauze) fabrics.
During the summer season, people may wear nagagi and haori, both made of ro (gauze) or sha (silk gauze) fabrics.
During the summer season, people may wear nagagi and haori, both made of ro (gauze) or sha (silk gauze) fabrics.

sen.j: くだけたものとしては黒以外の色の紋付を用いることもある。
sen.e: People may sometimes wear crested garments of other colors than black as casual clothings.
People may sometimes wear crested garments of other colors than black as casual clothings.
People may sometimes wear crested garments of other colors than black as casual clothings.

sen.j: 帯：角帯
sen.e: Belt: Kakuobi (a stiff sash for men)
Belt: Kakuobi (a stiff sash for men)
Belt: Kakuobi (a stiff sash for men)

sen.j: 袴
sen.e: Hakama (a formal pleated and divided skirt for men)
Hakama (a formal pleated and divided skirt for men)
Hakama (a formal pleated and divided skirt for men)

sen.j: 通常は仙台平など荒い縞地の絹織物が用いられ、無地の袴は略式とされる。
sen.e: Usually, silk fabrics of broad-striped pattern like Sendai-hira (a kind of silk fabrics for men's hakama skirts) are used to make hakama skirts for men, while plain hakama is regarded as informal.
Usually, silk fabrics of broad-striped pattern like Sendai-hira (a kind of silk fabrics for men's hakama skirts) are used to make hakama skirts for men, while plain hakama is regarded as informal.
Usually, silk fabrics of broad-striped pattern like Sendai-hira (a kind of silk fabrics for men's hakama skirts) are used to make hakama skirts for men, while plain hakama is regarded as informal.

sen.j: 現在では袴馬乗り袴・袴行灯袴ともに可とされているが、本来は馬乗袴を穿くものとされる。
sen.e: Today, it is allowed for men to wear both umanori-bakama (a kind of hakama skirt of horse-riding style) and andon-bakama (a kind of hakama skirt of tubular type), but men in nature are supposed to wear umanori-bakama.

Today, it is allowed for men to wear both umanori-bakama (a kind of hakama skirt of horse-riding style) and andon-bakama (a kind of hakama skirt of tubular type), but men in nature are supposed to wear umanori-bakama.

Today, it is allowed for men to wear both umanori-bakama (a kind of hakama skirt of horse-riding style) and andon-bakama (a kind of hakama skirt of tubular type), but men in nature are supposed to wear umanori-bakama.

sen.j: 足袋：白足袋に限る。
sen.e: Tabi (Japanese digitated socks): Only white tabi socks can be worn for this montsuki haori hakama style.
Tabi (Japanese digitated socks): Only white tabi socks can be worn for this Montsuki Haori Hakama style.
sen.cmt: Montsuki Haori Hakamaとし、余分なスペース消去
sen.e: Tabi (Japanese digitated socks): Only white tabi socks can be worn for this Montsuki Haori Hakama style.

sen.j: 履物：白鼻緒の雪駄に限る。
sen.e: Footwear: Only setta (Japanese traditional sandals) with white thongs can be worn for this style.
Footwear: Only setta (Japanese traditional sandals) with white thongs can be worn for this style.
Footwear: Only setta (Japanese traditional sandals) with white thongs can be worn for this style.

sen.j: 扇子：白扇。
sen.e: Sensu (a folding fan): White-ground sensu is held by a wearer of this garment.
Sensu (a folding fan): White-ground sensu is held by a wearer of this garment.
Sensu (a folding fan): White-ground sensu is held by a wearer of this garment.

tit.e: Usage:
Usage

sen.j: 結納
sen.e: On the occasion of a ceremonial exchange of betrothal gifts;
On the occasion of a ceremonial exchange of betrothal gifts
On the occasion of a ceremonial exchange of betrothal gifts

tit.e: On the occasion of a wedding ceremony;
On the occasion of a wedding ceremony
On the occasion of a wedding ceremony

sen.j: - 新郎や両家の父親、来賓など。
sen.e: This attire is worn by the groom, fathers of the bridal couple, guests and others.
This attire is worn by the groom, fathers of the bridal couple, guests and others.
This attire is worn by the groom, fathers of the bridal couple, guests and others.

tit.e: On the occasion of a ceremony for announcement of somebody's succession to a professional name;
On the occasion of a ceremony for announcement of somebody's succession to a professional name
On the occasion of a ceremony for announcement of somebody's succession to a professional name

sen.j: - 落語家などの襲名披露。
sen.e: For example, rakugo-ka (a comic story teller) wears this attire on the occasion of a ceremony for announcement of his succession to the new name.
For example, rakugo-ka (a comic story teller) wears this attire on the occasion of a ceremony for announcement of his succession to the new name.
For example, rakugo-ka (a comic story teller) wears this attire on the occasion of a ceremony for announcement of his succession to the new name.

tit.e: On the occasion of ozumo (a grand sumo tournament):
On the occasion of ozumo (a grand sumo tournament)
On the occasion of ozumo (a grand sumo tournament)

sen.j: - 関取の正装であり、また行司に物言いを行う審判員（勝負審判）が着用。
sen.e: Sekitori (sumo wrestlers ranked in the top two divisions) wear this attire as their formal dress, as well as shinpan-in (shobu-shinpan, or ringside judges who may claim their objection against referee's decision) wear it.

Sekitori (sumo wrestlers ranked in the top two divisions) wear this attire as their formal dress, as well as shinpan-in (shobu-shinpan, or ringside judges who may claim their objection against referee's decision) wear it.

Sekitori (sumo wrestlers ranked in the top two divisions) wear this attire as their formal dress, as well as shinpan-in (shobu-shinpan, or ringside judges who may claim their objection against referee's decision) wear it.

tit.e: On the occasion of a funeral:
On the occasion of a funeral
On the occasion of a funeral

sen.j: - 羽織の紐は祝儀の時と同様に白だが、黒や灰色を使用する風習もある。
sen.e: The color of braids of haori coat is equally white as in the case of auspicious events, but some customs allow to use black or grey braids for a funeral.
The color of braids of haori coat is equally white as in the case of auspicious events, but some customs allow to use black or grey braids for a funeral.
The color of braids of haori coat is equally white as in the case of auspicious events, but some customs allow to use black or grey braids for a funeral.

sen.j: 落語家
sen.e: In the case of rakugo-ka (a comic story teller):
In the case of rakugo-ka (a comic story teller)

sen.j: ‐ 二ツ目昇進後に着用が許される。
sen.e: Rakugo-ka (a comic story teller) is allowed to wear this attire after he gets a promotion of two stages.
Rakugo-ka (a comic story teller) is allowed to wear this attire after he gets a promotion of two stages.
Rakugo-ka (a comic story teller) is allowed to wear this attire after he gets a promotion of two stages.
